data.description:
Create high energy encounters with Naer – the Mixed Reality productivity app where colleagues collaborate in a truly hybrid, immersive workplace.

Set the timer and share ideas as fast as you can express them with telekinetic sticky notes. Your work merges directly into Miro, so you don’t have to worry about documentation.

Wherever you are, gather your team in one place, for fun, fast and intuitive workshops. 

Stuff you can do in Naer
- Mixed Reality for co-located and hybrid workshops
- Talk to your sticky notes (no need for a keyboard, they’ll listen)
- Integrate with Miro in realtime
- Share your computer screen
- Be fast with telekinetic superpowers
- Smooth vector drawing
- Keep track with a workshop timer
- Adjust the time of day to set the mood
- Bring your Meta Avatar

changelog.change_log:
Major release incoming!

First of all - Naer is now free to use for individuals and teams! 

For new people checking out Naer, you’ll be greeted with a brand-new tutorial. Thanks to 
Antonis, it is now much clearer what you need to do, and how the app works! Interacting in Naer has also become even smoother with our latest improvements to telekinesis.

We also welcome you to a new lobby with crisp panels and the ability to create rooms without taking off your headset! Sharing a headset? No problem, you can change the name of your avatar and your appearance right from the lobby. You even get faster into the room you visited last time because now it’s right at the top of the list! Nice one, Stig.

Thanks to our Keeper of Keys, Ingrid, you can now create room codes to share with others! The room codes remove the need for pairing headsets or being a part of a team to join a session in VR. Neat. She has also done a lot of things you don’t see, working in the shadows (like Batman).

Fixes & Improvements 
No more accidental muting of other participants! Antonis and Bengt Ove made it harder to mute others by mistake and also made improvements to the look and feel of the name tags. You now see who’s talking, and who is muted.  

Telekinesis is actually super hard to do well. Antonis has worked his a** off to provide you with better aiming, better animations, and better push and pull of content between you and the whiteboard. Based on where you look, we can now detect a whiteboard and understand if you intend to send the sticky note to the whiteboard or if you wish to delete it. It’s actually quite magical and even more natural to use. Try to look at the whiteboard while holding a sticky note and flicking your wrist like a wand and see for yourself!

Want to listen to some sweet tunes in Naer? Stig has improved the audio quality of the screen share stream, so feel free to host your very own cave rave. When sharing your computer screen in Naer, the screen size will also adapt to the content you are sharing - cool right? Lastly, we have moved the screen to the left side of the whiteboard so you don’t lose any of the whiteboard content when sharing your screen.

Lastly we fixed a rare issue where people could get disconnected for no good reason.

Bengt Ove rewrote pretty much our whole Miro integration from scratch, making sure it exceeds your expectations. It’s much more stable than before adding support for images, plain text, many shapes, and of course the humble sticky note.

Thanks to Ingrid, you can now create Miro boards directly from the web app. Newly created boards will automatically be added to your list of boards. She also made the onboarding super fast with auto-accepting invites if you already have an account.

Also, now might be a good time to beam your computer screen into Naer! 
Stig has made screen sharing much more reliable, and updated our dependencies to the latest and greatest to ensure we’re using their latest and most bug free features. And, if you enable screen sharing in VR before casting from the web app, Bengt Ove added some instructions on how to cast your screen. 

Lastly, Antonis has made improvements to super powers like telekinetic pulling, making it feel much more natural (really, try it. thank him later). Learning how to use Naer is now also easier since we have added videos to the tutorial, along with the already brilliant voice over. We also thought to align that mirror a bit better (mirror mirror on the wall, who is the best facilitator of them all?).
